Stickiness metric

Getting started

“Stickiness”, a longitudinal persistence metric introduced in 2012, tracks all students who contact an instructional program to determine what percentage “stick” to that program and graduate in it.1

Stickiness is defined as the ratio of the number of students graduating in a program to the number of students ever enrolled in the program.

In this article, we show you how to use midfieldr to compute and compare the stickiness of several programs. Our workflow is:

  • select the programs
  • count the students ever enrolled
  • count the students graduating
  • compute stickiness
  • graph stickiness

In our research, because we focus on intersectionality, we typically disaggregate the data by program, sex, and race/ethnicity. You may of course choose your own combination of variables to study.

library(midfieldr)       # midfieldr functions and CIP data
library(midfieldstudent) # student demographics and degree data
library(midfieldterm)    # term data

Select programs

For this example, we compare the stickiness of three engineering programs: Civil, Electrical, and Mechanical. Their CIP codes were found by keyword search as illustrated in Selecting CIP codes.

Use cip_filter() to obtain the relevant program codes followed by add_column() to label the group of programs. These labels are handy for grouping data and for titling graph panels.

# obtain 2, 4, and 6-digit CIP codes and names
library(dplyr)
library(tibble)
cve <- cip_filter("^1408") %>% add_column(PGRM = "Civil Engineering")
ele <- cip_filter("^1410") %>% add_column(PGRM = "Electrical Engineering")
mce <- cip_filter("^1419") %>% add_column(PGRM = "Mechanical Engineering")

Bind the program data sets into one data frame and discard all but two variables. The CIP6 variable contains the character strings used to filter students from the term and degree datasets; the PGRM variable is handy for grouping the data for counting and graphing.

# bind the four programs
programs <- bind_rows(cve, ele, mce) %>% 
    select(CIP6, PGRM)

# examine the result
programs
#>      CIP6                   PGRM
#> 1  140801      Civil Engineering
#> 2  140802      Civil Engineering
#> 3  140803      Civil Engineering
#> 4  140804      Civil Engineering
#> 5  140805      Civil Engineering
#> 6  140899      Civil Engineering
#> 7  141001 Electrical Engineering
#> 8  141003 Electrical Engineering
#> 9  141004 Electrical Engineering
#> 10 141099 Electrical Engineering
#> 11 141901 Mechanical Engineering

Count students ever enrolled

Use gather_ever() to subset the term dataset, retaining only those students ever enrolled in programs.

# gather students ever enrolled in the programs
ever <- gather_ever(term, programs)

# examine the result
glimpse(ever)
#> Observations: 58,306
#> Variables: 10
#> $ MID         <dbl> 820102025, 820102025, 820102025, 820102025, 820102...
#> $ BEGINYEAR   <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA...
#> $ TYEAR       <dbl> 2004, 2003, 2004, 2004, 2005, 1990, 1991, 1991, 19...
#> $ TTERM       <chr> "SP", "FA", "FA", "SM", "SP", "FA", "SP", "FA", "S...
#> $ INSTITUTION <chr> "Institution 1", "Institution 1", "Institution 1",...
#> $ TCIPN       <chr> "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "TCIP", "T...
#> $ CIP6        <chr> "140801", "140801", "140801", "140801", "140801", ...
#> $ PGRM        <chr> "Civil Engineering", "Civil Engineering", "Civil E...
#> $ ETHNIC      <chr> "No Response", "No Response", "No Response", "No R...
#> $ SEX         <chr> "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", ...

This is the point at which you decide how to group the student counts. Here, we disaggregate by race/ethnicity, sex, and program. The count() function creates a new variable n that we rename EVER.

# count ever enrolled by grouping variables 
ever_count <- dplyr::count(ever, PGRM, ETHNIC, SEX)  %>% 
    rename(EVER = n)

# examine the result
ever_count <- dplyr::arrange(ever_count, desc(EVER))
ever_count
#> # A tibble: 53 x 4
#>    PGRM                   ETHNIC          SEX    EVER
#>    <chr>                  <chr>           <chr> <int>
#>  1 Mechanical Engineering White           M     21092
#>  2 Civil Engineering      White           M     11146
#>  3 Electrical Engineering White           M      8029
#>  4 Civil Engineering      White           F      3080
#>  5 Mechanical Engineering White           F      2573
#>  6 Mechanical Engineering Hispanic/Latino M      1302
#>  7 Mechanical Engineering No Response     M      1071
#>  8 Electrical Engineering International   M       974
#>  9 Electrical Engineering White           F       961
#> 10 Mechanical Engineering International   M       953
#> # ... with 43 more rows

A graph gives us a sense of the data. The panels and rows of the graph are ordered by median numbers of students. Civil has the largest median; Electrical the smallest; White the largest median; Hawaiian/Pacific Islander the smallest.

# graph ever enrolled numbers 
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(ever_count, aes(x = EVER, y = reorder(ETHNIC, EVER, median), col = SEX)) +
    labs(x = "Number of students ever enrolled", y = "") +
    facet_wrap(~ reorder(PGRM, -EVER, median), ncol = 1) +
    geom_point(size = 2, alpha = 0.8) + 
    scale_color_manual(values = c(lightBr, lightBG)) +     # midfieldr custom color names
    expon_scale_x_log10() +                                # midfieldr custom scale layer
    midfield_theme()                                       # midfieldr custom theme

The graph code chunk includes custom arguments and layers:

  • lightBr and lightBG are named colors in midfieldr adapted from RColorBrewer
  • expon_scale_x_log10() produces powers-of-ten notation on the x scale
  • midfield_theme() is a custom theme based on theme_minimal()

For more information on midfieldr graph functions and arguments, ?graph_functions.
